page.title: 08Friday Bridge Water Tower
page.content: The water tower is in the middle of the village. It is used as a landmark for the land and air. It can be seen for miles and aeroplanes use it on training flights. It was built in 1884 for the outlying parishes of Wisbech and the Great Eastern Railway at March. The water tower is 112 feet high and has three floors. The water comes from Marham by gravity. At the side of the water tower is a big reservoir which contains a million gallons of water. The tank at the top of the water tower contains 100,000 gallons of water. The water got to the tower by pump and supplies the surrounding area. In 1981 a facelift was carried out at the cost of Â£10,000 to the water board. The tower's diesel booster pumps have been replaced with electronic ones to the north west of the tower.
